abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Energy Efficiency Project
            for Bangladesh is rated as unsatisfactory. The institutional
            impact is rated as negligible and the sustainability of any
            achievements is rated as unlikely. The project was approved
            in June 1988 and became effective in November 1989. The
            delay to effectiveness was mainly in finalizing the
            technical assistance contract with the two foreign
            consulting firms. Soon after effectiveness it became
            apparent that the 32 pre-identified public sector
            sub-projects, accounting for about 65 percent of expected
            sub-loan demand, were no longer qualified for the project.
            Most of the public sector sub-projects were ineligible
            because of their poor financial condition. The few that were
            eligible were unwilling to apply for sub-loans because they
            felt the credit terms and conditions, especially the market
            rate of interest, were unattractive. The project was
            therefore left with the 13 private sector energy
            conservation investments. However, none of these applied for
            financing under the project either. The lack of sub-loan
            demand for energy conservation investments jeopardized the
            attainment of project objectives. The Bank concurred with
            the Government's request and cancelled the project on
            April 7, 1992. No disbursements were made under the credit.
            No audit is planned. An analysis of the reasons for failure
            yielded four lessons learned. First, the essential
            underpinnings of project concept must be exhaustively
            reviewed. In hindsight, the project design was very poor and
            not enough background work was done. Second, market demand
            for funds need to be assessed realistically. Third,
            effectiveness conditions should be kept simple to avoid
            delays in fulfillment. Fourth, implementing agencies should
            be involved during project preparation to create a sense of ownership.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Industrial Energy Efficiency Project
            aims to: (a) reduce energy consumption per unit of output in
            economically and financially viable industrial and power
            plants, thereby reinforcing the overall industrial sector
            objectives of higher efficiency and increased
            competitiveness. It also seeks to (b) promote development of
            appropriate policies, technologies and institutional
            framework to further strengthen the country's energy
            rationalization program. The project consists of two
            components: (a) a line of credit for financing about 50
            energy conservation subprojects; and (b) technical
            assistance for further strengthening of EMU and improving
            appraisal capability of Agrani Bank for energy conservation subprojects.
